name: wood chipping, mobile chipper, at forest road | wood chipping, chipper, mobile, diesel, at forest road | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10680/documentation

The inventory refers to 1 productive machine hour (PMS) - referring to the operational time of the machine including breaks up to 15 minutes - of a mobile chipper mounted on a lorry;This dataset refers to a chipping unit including a separate engine, a mobile crane and supportive structure with a total weight of 19,200 kg mounted on a lorry chassis of 9.800 kg. The engine power is assumed to be 475 kW (350 kW for diesel engine and 125 kW for hydraulic system) with a diesel consumption of 70 l/PMH. For assumed service life, see data set on operation of respective machinery.;Assumed fuel consumption: 70.0 l/PMH; total service life: 15,000 PMH, average daily transport distance of machinery: 60 km.;Productivity depends on the specific circumstances of the harvesting operation and is specified in the respective datasets.;The following sources have been consulted for the elaboration and plausibilisation of the dataset:;    Anonymous (2004): DIRECTIVE 2004/26/EC OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 21 April 2004 amending Directive 97/68/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to measures against the emission of gaseous and particulate pollutants from internal combustion engines to be installed in non-road mobile machinery. Official Journal of the European Union: 30.4.2004;    Athanassiadis, D., G. Lidestav and I. Wästerlund (1999): Fuel, hydraulic oil and lubricant consumption in Swedish mechanized harvesting operations, 1996. Journal of Forest Engineering, 10(1): 59-66.;     Cremer, T. and B. Velazques-Marti (2007): Evaluation of two harvesting systems for the supply of wood-chips in Norway spurce forest affected by bark beetle. Croation Journal of Forest Engineering, 28(2): 145-155. ;   Fobrig, A. (2004): Holzernteverfahren; Vergleichende Erhebung und Beurteilung der Holzernteverfahren in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland; im Anhalt an KWF-Bericht Nr. 25 (Holzernteverfahren) und diverse Tagungsführer der KWF-Tagungen. Kuratorium für Waldarbeit und Forsttechnik e.V. (KWF), Gross-Umstadt.;     Gustavsson, L., L. N. Eriksson and R. Sathre (2011): Costs and CO2 benefits of recovering, refining and transporting logging residues for fossil fuel replacement. Applied Energy, 88(1): 192-197.;      Kilpeläinen, A., A. Alam, H. Strandman and S. Kellomäki (2011): Life cycle assessment tool for estimating net CO2 exchange of forest production. GCM Bionenergy: 1-11. doi: 10.1111/j.1757-1707.2011.01101.x     ;   Klvac, R. and A. Skoupy (2009): Characteristic fuel consumption and exhaust emissions in fully mechanized logging operations. Journal of Forest Research, 14(6): 328-334: referring to Freitas 2004.;     Riezinger, A. (2008): Die Ermittlung der ökologischen Effizienz der Bereitstellungskette von Waldhackgut anhand ausgewählter Fallstudien; Diplomarbeit. Universität der Bodenkultur (BOKU), Wien.;    Spielmann, M., L. Barreto, V. Erni, F. Frutig and O. Thees (2007): Life cycle assessment of energy wood chip supply chains; a case study of near future supply of forest wood chips in Switzerland (unpublished). Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), Swiss Federal Institute for Forest, Snow and Landscape Research (WSL), Villigen, Birmensdorf.;     Talbot, B. and K. Suadicani (2007): Analysis of Two Simulated In-field Chipping and Extraction Systems in Spruce Thinnings. Biosystems Engineering, 91(3): 283-292. ;;    Wittkopf, S., U. Hömer and S. Feller (2003): Bereitstellungsverfahren für Waldhackschnitzel - Leistungen, Kosten, Rahmenbedingungen. Bayer. Landesanstalt für Wald und Forstwirtschaft, Freising.

Service beginning with the transport of the machinery to the logging site.

Includes the input of machinery infrastructure, the input of diesel fuel, lubricants/greases as well as their disposal, and the emissions into air from diesel consumption. Wood is not included in the dataset.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/022:Logging/0220:Logging

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Emission profile according to European legislation
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Material and fuel input from literature sources (see general comments field); air-borne emissions taken from existing dataset on diesel consumption in building machines or - where emission levels beyond applicable European legislation - estimated with emissions model based on emission limits established in European Directive 2004/ 26/EC for non-road mobile machinery types EURO IIIa and IIIb (according to Lambrecht et al 2004 and e.g. applied in Spielmann et al. 2007).

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description: emission model calculating hourly specific emissions as "engine power x load factor x base emission factor" as proposed by Lambrecht et al. (2004) and applied in Spielmann et al. (2007);  values for base emission factors for VOC for vehicle classes EURO IIIa and EURO IIIb are taken from Guideline 97/68/EG, of which 97.6% are assumed to be NMVOC.

exchanges.description: emission model calculating hourly specific emissions as "engine power x load factor x base emission factor" as proposed by Lambrecht et al. (2004) and applied in Spielmann et al. (2007); values for base emission factors for particles for mobile machine classes EURO IIIa and EUROIIIb are taken from European Directive 2004/ 26/EC. The proportional distribution accross particle classes is made based on the ecoinvent v3 dataset "Diesel, burned in building machine/GLO".

exchanges.description: emission model calculating hourly specific emissions as "engine power x load factor x base emission factor" as proposed by Lambrecht et al. (2004) and applied in Spielmann et al. (2007);  values for base emission factors for NOx for mobile machine class EUROIIIb are taken from the European Directive 2004/ 26/EC; for mobile machine class EURO IIIa values for base emission factors for NOx are calculated based on an assumed reduction of VOC emissions as compared to "Tier 2" limit for VOC of 1.0 g/kWh (following Spielmann et al. 2007).
